summary:
Kwang Taik Kim, Ph.D., is a Research Assistant Professor of Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Purdue University.
As a communications and networking researcher, he is particularly interested in 5G/NextG ajar/open RAN architectures, open edge platforms, implementation aspects of digital communications, real-time wireless networking protocols and large-scale distributed computing, and machine learning in the realms of wireless system design. His research is primarily focused on providing feasibility studies for cutting-edge theoretical breakthroughs in wireless communications and networking through experimentation with 5G and NextG wireless systems.

Opportunities Graduate Research Openings There are openings for graduate students in my group. I encourage prospective students with an interest in 5G/NextG wireless systems and edge computing to apply to the ECE graduate program at Purdue. If you have already been admitted to Purdue, please send me an email and I'd be happy to chat further. Undergraduate Research Openings I have openings for Purdue undergraduates that are interested in participating in research projects and gaining expertise.

Overview of Research Projects The current research thrusts of my group focus on: 5G/NextG ajar/open architectures of radio access networks, real-time edge platform architectures, air-interface & networking protocol designs, and experiementation (e.g., https://indiana5gzone.com, https://ninetwelveconvergence.us) to provide feasibility and resilience studies for state-of-the-art theoretical advances in wireless communications & networking, core, and edge computing.
Content Publications Book Chapters Granted Patents Publications Multi-Edge Server-Assisted Dynamic Federated Learning with an Optimized Floating Aggregation Point Bhargav Ganguly, Seyyedali Hosseinalipour, Kwang Taik Kim, Christopher Brinton, Vaneet Aggarwal, David Love, Mung Chiang accepted in IEEE/ACM Trans.

Overview of Research Projects My research interests are in real-time platform architectures and experimentation in 5G and Next G wireless systems.
One of major challenges that we see is that there is a gap between theory and practice. So, the goal of most of my research is to provide feasibility studies for state-of-the-art theoretical advances in wireless communications.
